timeline.message:
Reduce DefaultAttributeMap cost

Motivation:

DefaultAttributeMap::attr has a blocking behaviour even on an existing attribute:
it can be made non-blocking.

Modification:

Replace the existing fixed bucket table with a locked intrusive linked list
with JCTools NonBlockingIdentityHashMap

Result:
Non blocking behaviour for the happy path, in case of hash collisions

timeline.bodyText: Just curious, why change from extending AtomicReference?
timeline.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: Because the old semantic wasn't documenting how to manage a removed state and now it doesn't match anymore the atomic reference one eg Attribute::get was === with AtomicReference::get. I have strengthened the new semantic to reduce the size of the default attribute instance ;)
replies.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText: OK sure, though I think you could still have just overridden those and used super.get() etc? Only for a slight simplification i.e. avoid needing the ARFU. Fine to leave as-is too
replies.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: I have chosen to not do that because at the beginning I have already tried it and found that the whole thing was compiling fine but failing some tests because of the ARFU existing implementation: it tooks me a bit to fine the issue so I have thought was a kind of semantic code smell and fixing it was I have currently done :)
replies.author: franz1981

timeline.author: njhill

timeline.bodyText: Is this the same as the old behavior? i.e. if the attribute was already removed from the map would its value still be set
timeline.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: Nope but there was no documentation about it so I have changed it into something that would reduce the memory footprint of the instance while keeping a consistent behaviour
replies.author: franz1981

timeline.bodyText: might be a nit, but did you consider binary searching to find the insertion point, and then use System.arraycopy to move the daat around for the slot?  I am curious if this more easily intrinsifies this for loop copy.
timeline.author: carl-mastrangelo

replies.bodyText: As a general rule of thumb, yes, you're right, here I have taken advantage of the domain logic where latest addition of attributes tends to have higher IDs (due to the incremental logic on constants).
replies.author: franz1981

timeline.bodyText: This doesn't seem to take advantage of the index which should be the insertion point.    I would suspect after a few attrs, avoiding the excess copies would become expensive.    It feels like the index should be passed into orderedCopyOnInsert
